Inverse Trigonometric Functions

Defining Them

In order to define inverse trig functions, we need to find domains so that they are one-to-one without changing their ranges. Because trig functions oscillate, there are a lot of intervals like these, so which one do we take? 000 is a nice number, so we are going to look for a domain containing 000 which doesn't change the range of our function.

Take a look at the graph of sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx:

As you can see, [−π2,π2]\br{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}}[−2π​,2π​] does the trick. On this interval, sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx passes the horizontal line test and it hits every point in its range, [−1,1]\br{-1, 1}[−1,1].

Now look at cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx:

There are two intervals in this case: [−π,0]\br{-\pi, 0}[−π,0] and [0,π]\br{0, \pi}[0,π]. Hopefully, you agree that [0,π]\br{0, \pi}[0,π] is "nicer" than the other one since it contains only positive numbers, so we're going to restrict cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx to [0,π]\br{0, \pi}[0,π] when defining the inverse.

The last one we're going to look at is tan⁡x\tan{x}tanx:

As in the case with cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx, we have multiple choices, but I think it's clear that (−π2,π2)\p{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}}(−2π​,2π​) is the "nicest" interval we can use.

We can play the same game with the rest of the trig functions, and what we get are the following inverse functions:

Definition (inverse trigonometric functions)

We define the inverses of trig functions via the following tables:

f(x)f−1(x)rangesin⁡xarcsin⁡x[−π2,π2]csc⁡xarccsc⁡x[−π2,0)∪(0,π2]tan⁡xarctan⁡x(−π2,π2)\def\arraystretch{1.5} \begin{array}{lll} f\p{x} & f^{-1}\p{x} & \text{range} \\ \hline \sin{x} & \arcsin{x} & \br{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}} \\ \csc{x} & \arccsc{x} & \left\lbrack -\frac{\pi}{2}, 0 \right\rparen \cup \left\lparen 0, \frac{\pi}{2} \right\rbrack \\ \tan{x} & \arctan{x} & \p{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}} \end{array}f(x)sinxcscxtanx​f−1(x)arcsinxarccscxarctanx​range[−2π​,2π​][−2π​,0)∪(0,2π​](−2π​,2π​)​​
f(x)f−1(x)rangecos⁡xarccos⁡x[0,π]sec⁡xarcsec⁡x[0,π2)∪(π2,π]cot⁡xarccot⁡x(0,π)\def\arraystretch{1.5} \begin{array}{lll} f\p{x} & f^{-1}\p{x} & \text{range} \\ \hline \cos{x} & \arccos{x} & \br{0, \pi} \\ \sec{x} & \arcsec{x} & \left\lbrack 0, \frac{\pi}{2} \right\rparen \cup \left\lparen \frac{\pi}{2}, \pi \right\rbrack \\ \cot{x} & \arccot{x} & \p{0, \pi} \end{array}f(x)cosxsecxcotx​f−1(x)arccosxarcsecxarccotx​range[0,π][0,2π​)∪(2π​,π](0,π)​​

We get the range of f−1(x)f^{-1}\p{x}f−1(x) by swapping the domain and range of f(x)f\p{x}f(x).

Exercise 1.

Figure out the domains of the inverse trig functions.

One thing to notice is how I arranged the tables. If you look at the top table, the ranges are all [−π2,π2]\br{-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}}[−2π​,2π​] with some points removed, i.e., the range of arcsin⁡x\arcsin{x}arcsinx with some points removed. Similarly, the bottom table ranges are all the range of arccos⁡x\arccos{x}arccosx with some points removed.

The way I remember how to group them are as follows: if sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx is the "main" function (e.g., csc⁡x=1sin⁡x\csc{x} = \frac{1}{\sin{x}}cscx=sinx1​), then the range is related to arcsin⁡x\arcsin{x}arcsinx. Similarly, if cos⁡x\cos{x}cosx is the "main" function, then the range will be related to arccos⁡x\arccos{x}arccosx.

Their Derivatives

Now that we have the inverses, let's talk about their derivatives. They are given in the following theorem:

Theorem
ddxarcsin⁡x=−11−x2ddxarccos⁡x=−11−x2ddxarctan⁡x=−11+x2ddxarcsec⁡x=−1∣x∣x2−1ddxarccsc⁡x=−1∣x∣x2−1ddxarccot⁡x=−11+x2\begin{aligned} &\deriv{}{x} \arcsin{x} &=& \phantom{-}\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arccos{x} &=& -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arctan{x} &=& \phantom{-}\frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arcsec{x} &=& \phantom{-}\frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arccsc{x} &=& -\frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} \\ &\deriv{}{x} \arccot{x} &=& -\frac{1}{1 + x^2} \\ \end{aligned}​dxd​arcsinxdxd​arccosxdxd​arctanxdxd​arcsecxdxd​arccscxdxd​arccotx​======​−1−x2​1​−1−x2​1​−1+x21​−∣x∣x2−1​1​−∣x∣x2−1​1​−1+x21​​

These are all done by implicit differentiation, and I'll show one of them:

Example 1.

Prove that ddxarcsec⁡x=1∣x∣x2−1\deriv{}{x} \arcsec{x} = \frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}dxd​arcsecx=∣x∣x2−1​1​.
Solution.

To start, I'm going to set y=arcsec⁡xy = \arcsec{x}y=arcsecx. Since arcsec⁡x\arcsec{x}arcsecx and sec⁡x\sec{x}secx are inverses, we can apply sec⁡θ\sec{\theta}secθ to both sides to get sec⁡y=x\sec{y} = xsecy=x. Now we can take derivatives on both sides to get

(sec⁡ytan⁡y)y′=1  ⟹  y′=1sec⁡ytan⁡y.\p{\sec{y}\tan{y}} y' = 1 \implies y' = \frac{1}{\sec{y}\tan{y}}.(secytany)y′=1⟹y′=secytany1​.

To finish the problem, we need to get the right-hand side in terms of xxx. We already know that sec⁡y=x\sec{y} = xsecy=x, so we need to handle tan⁡y\tan{y}tany. We can use the following trig identity to relate tan⁡y\tan{y}tany to sec⁡y=x\sec{y} = xsecy=x:

tan⁡2y+1=sec⁡2y=x2  ⟹  tan⁡2y=x2−1  ⟹  tan⁡y=±x2−1.\begin{aligned} \tan^2{y} + 1 = \sec^2{y} = x^2 &\implies \tan^2{y} = x^2 - 1 \\ &\implies \tan{y} = \pm\sqrt{x^2 - 1}. \end{aligned}tan2y+1=sec2y=x2​⟹tan2y=x2−1⟹tany=±x2−1​.​

We need to figure out when the sign is positive and when the sign is negative, so we need to break it into two cases:

Case 1: sec⁡y=x>0\sec{y} = x > 0secy=x>0

Since y=arcsec⁡xy = \arcsec{x}y=arcsecx, yyy is in the range of arcsec⁡x\arcsec{x}arcsecx, so yyy is in the first or second quadrant.

Since sec⁡y>0\sec{y} > 0secy>0, this means that cos⁡y>0\cos{y} > 0cosy>0, which means that yyy must be in Quadrant I. In this quadrant, tan⁡y>0\tan{y} > 0tany>0, so tan⁡y=x2−1\tan{y} = \sqrt{x^2 - 1}tany=x2−1​ in this case.

Case 2: sec⁡y=x<0\sec{y} = x < 0secy=x<0

We can use the same argument: in this case, cos⁡y<0\cos{y} < 0cosy<0, so yyy is in Quadrant II, which means that tan⁡y<0\tan{y} < 0tany<0. Thus, tan⁡y=−x2−1\tan{y} = -\sqrt{x^2 - 1}tany=−x2−1​ in this case.

Now that we have established the signs of tan⁡y\tan{y}tany, we just need to plug it back into our original function. There are two cases, so we end up with a piecewise function:

y′=1xtan⁡y={1−xx2−1if x>01−xx2−1if x<0=1∣x∣x2−1.\begin{aligned} y' &= \frac{1}{x\tan{y}} \\ &= \begin{cases} \dfrac{1}{\phantom{-}x\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} & \text{if } x > 0 \\[2ex] \dfrac{1}{-x\sqrt{x^2 - 1}} & \text{if } x < 0 \end{cases} \\ &= \frac{1}{\abs{x}\sqrt{x^2 - 1}}. \end{aligned}y′​=xtany1​=⎩⎨⎧​−xx2−1​1​−xx2−1​1​​if x>0if x<0​=∣x∣x2−1​1​.​

The last equality comes from the fact that ∣x∣=x\abs{x} = x∣x∣=x if x>0x > 0x>0 and −x-x−x if x<0x < 0x<0.
Exercise 2.

Prove the rest of the derivatives.

Compounding Interest Monthly

This is the setup: we have an initial amount of money (the principal) P0P_0P0​, an interest rate rrr which is compounded nnn times a year, and we want to know how much money we have after ttt years.

"Compunded nnn times a year" means that we calculate interest with the rate rn\frac{r}{n}nr​ a total of nnn times each year. So, after the first compounding, we get P0(rn)P_0\p{\frac{r}{n}}P0​(nr​) dollars in interest, which brings our total to P0+P0(rn)=P0(1+rn)P_0 + P_0\p{\frac{r}{n}} = P_0\p{1 + \frac{r}{n}}P0​+P0​(nr​)=P0​(1+nr​).

After the second time, we get P0(1+rn)rnP_0\p{1 + \frac{r}{n}}\frac{r}{n}P0​(1+nr​)nr​ in interest, which gives us P0(1+rn)2P_0\p{1 + \frac{r}{n}}^2P0​(1+nr​)2 total, etc. You should be able to see the pattern: after 111 year, you will have compounded interest nnn times, so you end up with P0(1+rn)nP_0\p{1 + \frac{r}{n}}^nP0​(1+nr​)n. Since we want to know how much we have in ttt years, we get the formula

P(t)=P0(1+rn)nt.P\p{t} = P_0\p{1 + \frac{r}{n}}^{nt}.P(t)=P0​(1+nr​)nt.

If we compound monthly, we compound 121212 times a year, so you use the formula n=12n = 12n=12. And, for example, if we compound biannually, then we compound twice a year, so you would use the formula with n=2n = 2n=2.

As nnn gets very, very large, we essentially compound interest every moment, i.e., we're compounding interest continuously. So, it's no surprise that

lim⁡n→∞P0(1+rn)nt=P0ert,\lim_{n\to\infty} P_0\p{1 + \frac{r}{n}}^{nt} = P_0e^{rt},n→∞lim​P0​(1+nr​)nt=P0​ert,

i.e., we get the formula for continuously compounded interest.

Exercise 3.

Prove the limit, e.g., using L'Hôpital's rule or by using the limit definition of eee.

L'Hôpital's Rule

This rule will probably be the one thing you remember from this class:

Theorem (L'Hôpital's rule)

Suppose fff and ggg satisfy the following conditions:

  1. fff and ggg are differentiable in an open interval around aaa
  2. lim⁡x→af(x)=lim⁡x→ag(x)=0\lim_{x \to a} f\p{x} = \lim_{x \to a} g\p{x} = 0limx→a​f(x)=limx→a​g(x)=0 or lim⁡x→af(x)=lim⁡x→ag(x)=±∞\lim_{x \to a} f\p{x} = \lim_{x \to a} g\p{x} = \pm\inftylimx→a​f(x)=limx→a​g(x)=±∞ (they are allowed to have different signs)
  3. g′(x)≠0g'\p{x} \neq 0g′(x)=0 in an open interval around aaa except possibly at x=ax = ax=a
  4. lim⁡x→af′(x)g′(x)\lim_{x \to a} \frac{f'\p{x}}{g'\p{x}}limx→a​g′(x)f′(x)​ exists or is infinite

Then

lim⁡x→af(x)g(x)=lim⁡x→af′(x)g′(x).\lim_{x \to a} \frac{f\p{x}}{g\p{x}} = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f'\p{x}}{g'\p{x}}.x→alim​g(x)f(x)​=x→alim​g′(x)f′(x)​.

Assumpion (i) is there just so you can take derivatives, and (iii) is just there to make sure that the limit makes sense. For example, what is lim⁡x→0x0\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{x}{0}limx→0​0x​? It's a meaningless expression, which is what we want to avoid.

So, the only assumptions that really make a difference are (ii) and (iv).

Pitfalls

It can be relatively easy to make mistakes when using L'Hôpital's, and the worst part is that they don't look like mistakes most of the time. So, here are a couple common pitfalls:

Don't use the quotient rule!

For example, L'Hôpital's rule does not tell you that

lim⁡x→∞xex=lim⁡x→∞ex−xexe2x.(wrong)\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{x}{e^x} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{e^x - xe^x}{e^{2x}}. \quad\text{(wrong)}x→∞lim​exx​=x→∞lim​e2xex−xex​.(wrong)

Instead, it tells you

lim⁡x→∞xex=lim⁡x→∞1ex=0.(right)\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{x}{e^x} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{e^x} = 0. \quad\text{(right)}x→∞lim​exx​=x→∞lim​ex1​=0.(right)

Check assumptions!

Make sure you are allowed to use L'Hôpital's before actually using it. This seems obvious, but it happens more than you think. Before you take derivatives, it's good to build the habit of checking that you have an indeterminate form. Here's an example that doesn't satisfy condition (ii):

lim⁡x→0x2cos⁡x=lim⁡x→0−2xsin⁡x=−2.(wrong)\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{x^2}{\cos{x}} = \lim_{x \to 0} -\frac{2x}{\sin{x}} = -2. \quad\text{(wrong)}x→0lim​cosxx2​=x→0lim​−sinx2x​=−2.(wrong)

This is incorrect because you don't have an indeterminate form, but it doesn't even look like a mistake, which it's why it's so important to be careful when using the rule. Instead, for this problem, you can plug in x=0x = 0x=0 directly to get 000.

Here's another example which satisfies condition (ii) but violates condition (iv):

lim⁡x→∞x+sin⁡xx=lim⁡x→∞1+cos⁡x1=DNE.\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{x + \sin{x}}{x} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1 + \cos{x}}{1} = \mathrm{DNE}.x→∞lim​xx+sinx​=x→∞lim​11+cosx​=DNE.

This does not mean that the limit does not exist; instead, it only tells you that L'Hôpital's rule is inconclusive here. Indeed, even though the limit of the derivatives does not exist, the original limit does exist:

lim⁡x→∞x+sin⁡xx⋅1x1x=lim⁡x→∞1+sin⁡xx1=1.\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{x + \sin{x}}{x} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{x}}{\frac{1}{x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1 + \frac{\sin{x}}{x}}{1} = 1.x→∞lim​xx+sinx​⋅x1​x1​​=x→∞lim​11+xsinx​​=1.

L'Hôpital's does not mean that old techniques are useless now!

Consider this limit:

lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x=lim⁡x→∞ex+e−xex−e−x=lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x=⋯\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{e^x + e^{-x}}{e^x - e^{-x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} = \cdotsx→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​=x→∞lim​ex−e−xex+e−x​=x→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​=⋯

As you can see, repeatedly using L'Hôpital's doesn't do anything for you, since you just end up with the original limit again. Instead, you can multiply and divide by e−xe^{-x}e−x, which gives

lim⁡x→∞ex−e−xex+e−x⋅e−xe−x=lim⁡x→∞1−e−2x1+e−2x=1.\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{e^x - e^{-x}}{e^x + e^{-x}} \cdot \frac{e^{-x}}{e^{-x}} = \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1 - e^{-2x}}{1 + e^{-2x}} = 1.x→∞lim​ex+e−xex−e−x​⋅e−xe−x​=x→∞lim​1+e−2x1−e−2x​=1.

Examples

Example 2.

Calculate lim⁡x→0+sin⁡x−x21−cos⁡2x\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\sin{x} - x^2}{\sqrt{1 - \cos^2{x}}}limx→0+​1−cos2x​sinx−x2​.
Solution.

Before using L'Hôpital's, you should always take a minute to see if you can simplify anything. In this problem, if you don't do that, you end up with a horrible derivative in the denominator. But if you do simplify, you will just get sin⁡x\sin{x}sinx in the bottom—much nicer! If you use L'Hôpital's after this, you just get

lim⁡x→0+sin⁡x−x21−cos⁡2x=lim⁡x→0+sin⁡x−x2sin⁡x=lim⁡x→0+cos⁡x−2xcos⁡x=1.\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\sin{x} - x^2}{\sqrt{1 - \cos^2{x}}} = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\sin{x} - x^2}{\sin{x}} = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\cos{x} - 2x}{\cos{x}} = \boxed{1}.x→0+lim​1−cos2x​sinx−x2​=x→0+lim​sinxsinx−x2​=x→0+lim​cosxcosx−2x​=1​.
Example 3.

Calculate lim⁡x→0+x2x\lim_{x \to 0^+} x^{2\sqrt{x}}limx→0+​x2x​.
Solution.

Here, we're going to want to use logarithms to bring the exponent down, so first set y=x2xy = x^{2\sqrt{x}}y=x2x​. Then we simply need to calculate lim⁡x→0+ln⁡y\lim_{x \to 0^+} \ln{y}limx→0+​lny: (I will put an HHH when I use L'Hôpital's rule)

lim⁡x→0+ln⁡y=lim⁡x→0+2xln⁡x=lim⁡x→0+2ln⁡x1x=lim⁡x→0+2ln⁡xx−1/2=Hlim⁡x→0+2x−12x−3/2=lim⁡x→0+−4x⋅x3/2=lim⁡x→0+−4x1/2=0.\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0^+} \ln{y} = \lim_{x \to 0^+} 2\sqrt{x} \ln{x} &= \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{2\ln{x}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{2\ln{x}}{x^{-1/2}} \\ &\overset{H}= \lim_{x\to0^+} \frac{\frac{2}{x}}{-\frac{1}{2}x^{-3/2}} \\ &= \lim_{x\to0^+} -\frac{4}{x} \cdot x^{3/2} \\ &= \lim_{x\to0^+} -4x^{1/2} \\ &= 0. \end{aligned}x→0+lim​lny=x→0+lim​2x​lnx​=x→0+lim​x​1​2lnx​=x→0+lim​x−1/22lnx​=Hx→0+lim​−21​x−3/2x2​​=x→0+lim​−x4​⋅x3/2=x→0+lim​−4x1/2=0.​

Finally, we need to evaluate the original limit:

lim⁡x→0+y=lim⁡x→0+eln⁡y=elim⁡x→0+ln⁡y=e0=1.\lim_{x \to 0^+} y = \lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{\ln{y}} = e^{\lim_{x \to 0^+} \ln{y}} = e^0 = \boxed{1}.x→0+lim​y=x→0+lim​elny=elimx→0+​lny=e0=1​.
Example 4.

Calculate lim⁡x→∞∣x+1x−2∣x2−4\lim_{x \to \infty} \abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}^{\sqrt{x^2 - 4}}limx→∞​∣∣​x−2x+1​∣∣​x2−4​.
Solution.

Like in the previous example, we're going to set y=∣x+1x−2∣x2−4y = \abs{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}^{\sqrt{x^2 - 4}}y=∣∣​x−2x+1​∣∣​x2−4​. Then

lim⁡x→∞ln⁡y=lim⁡x→∞x2−4ln⁡(x+1x−2)=lim⁡x→∞ln⁡(x+1x−2)1x2−4=lim⁡x→∞ln⁡(x+1)−ln⁡(x−2)(x2−4)−1/2=Hlim⁡x→∞1x+1−1x−2−x(x2−4)−3/2=lim⁡x→∞x−2(x+1)(x−2)−x+1(x+1)(x−2)−x⋅(x2−4)3/2=lim⁡x→∞−3(x2−4)3/2−x(x+1)(x−2)=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4)3/2x(x+1)(x−2)\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \infty} \ln{y} &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \sqrt{x^2 - 4}\ln\p{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\ln\p{\frac{x + 1}{x - 2}}}{\frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 - 4}}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\ln\p{x + 1} - \ln\p{x - 2}}{\p{x^2 - 4}^{-1/2}} \\ &\overset{H}{=} \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\frac{1}{x+1} - \frac{1}{x-2}}{-x\p{x^2 - 4}^{-3/2}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\frac{x-2}{\p{x+1}\p{x-2}} - \frac{x+1}{\p{x+1}\p{x-2}}}{-x} \cdot \p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{-3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}}{-x\p{x+1}\p{x-2}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}}{x\p{x+1}\p{x-2}} \end{aligned}x→∞lim​lny​=x→∞lim​x2−4​ln(x−2x+1​)=x→∞lim​x2−4​1​ln(x−2x+1​)​=x→∞lim​(x2−4)−1/2ln(x+1)−ln(x−2)​=Hx→∞lim​−x(x2−4)−3/2x+11​−x−21​​=x→∞lim​−x(x+1)(x−2)x−2​−(x+1)(x−2)x+1​​⋅(x2−4)3/2=x→∞lim​−x(x+1)(x−2)−3(x2−4)3/2​=x→∞lim​x(x+1)(x−2)3(x2−4)3/2​​

When xxx is large, (x2−4)3/2\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}(x2−4)3/2 is roughly (x2)3/2=x3\p{x^2}^{3/2} = x^3(x2)3/2=x3, and the denominator is also roughly x3x^3x3. So, we will multiply and divide by 1x3\frac{1}{x^3}x31​. Notice that x3=(x2)3/2x^3 = \p{x^2}^{3/2}x3=(x2)3/2, which gives

=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4)3/2x(x+1)(x+2)⋅1x31x3=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4)3/2(1x2)3/2x(x+1)(x−2)x3=lim⁡x→∞3(x2−4x2)3/2xxx+1xx−2x=lim⁡x→∞3(1−4x2)3/2(1+1x)(1−2x)=3.\begin{aligned} &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2}}{x\p{x+1}\p{x+2}} \cdot \frac{\frac{1}{x^3}}{\frac{1}{x^3}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{x^2 - 4}^{3/2} \p{\frac{1}{x^2}}^{3/2}}{\frac{x\p{x+1}\p{x-2}}{x^3}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{\frac{x^2 - 4}{x^2}}^{3/2}}{\frac{x}{x} \frac{x+1}{x} \frac{x-2}{x}} \\ &= \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3\p{1 - \frac{4}{x^2}}^{3/2}}{\p{1 + \frac{1}{x}}\p{1 - \frac{2}{x}}} \\ &= 3. \end{aligned}​=x→∞lim​x(x+1)(x+2)3(x2−4)3/2​⋅x31​x31​​=x→∞lim​x3x(x+1)(x−2)​3(x2−4)3/2(x21​)3/2​=x→∞lim​xx​xx+1​xx−2​3(x2x2−4​)3/2​=x→∞lim​(1+x1​)(1−x2​)3(1−x24​)3/2​=3.​

Finally, we just need to go back to the original limit. By continuity,

lim⁡x→0+y=lim⁡x→0+eln⁡y=elim⁡x→0+ln⁡y=e3.\lim_{x \to 0^+} y = \lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{\ln{y}} = e^{\lim_{x \to 0^+} \ln{y}} = \boxed{e^3}.x→0+lim​y=x→0+lim​elny=elimx→0+​lny=e3​.
